children.value: file supports a number of built-in scripts and their preset life cycle events as well as arbitrary scripts. These all can be executed by running
commands with matching names will be run for those as well (e.g.
). Scripts from dependencies can be run with
To create "pre" or "post" scripts for any scripts defined in the
and add "pre" or "post" to the beginning of them.

{
  "scripts": {
    "precompress": "{{ executes BEFORE the `compress` script }}",
    "compress": "{{ run command to compress files }}",
    "postcompress": "{{ executes AFTER `compress` script }}"
  }
}
There are some special life cycle scripts that happen only in certain situations. These scripts happen in addtion to the "pre" and "post" script.
Runs BEFORE the package is packed
Runs BEFORE the package is published

Runs AFTER the tarball has been generated and moved to its final destination.

If you need to perform operations on your package before it is used, in a way that is not dependent on the operating system or architecture of the target system, use a
script. This includes tasks such as:
Compiling CoffeeScript source code into JavaScript.
Creating minified versions of JavaScript source code.
Fetching remote resources that your package will use.
The advantage of doing these things at
time is that they can be done once, in a single place, thus reducing complexity and variability. Additionally, this means that:

, and thus
your users don't need to have it installed.

You don't need to include minifiers in your package, reducing
the size for your users.
You don't need to rely on your users having

or
other system tools on the target machines.
npm will default some script values based on package contents.

If npm was invoked with root privileges, then it will change the uid
to the user account or uid specified by the

flag to run scripts with
root privileges.

Package scripts run in an environment where many pieces of information
are made available regarding the setup of npm and the current state of
the process.

If you depend on modules that define executable scripts, like test
suites, then those executables will be added to the

for
executing the scripts. So, if your package.json has this:

{
  "name": "foo",
  "dependencies": {
    "bar": "0.1.x"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "start": "bar ./test"
  }
}

script, which is
exported into the
The package.json fields are tacked onto the

prefix. So,
for instance, if you had

in your
package.json file, then your package scripts would have the
environment variable set to "foo", and the

set to "1.2.5". You can access these variables
in your code with
, and so on for other fields.
Configuration parameters are put in the environment with the
prefix. For instance, you can view the effective

The package.json "config" keys are overwritten in the environment if
there is a config param of

. For example,
if the package.json has this:

{
  "name": "foo",
  "config": {
    "port": "8080"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node server.js"
  }
}
http.createServer(...).listen(process.env.npm_package_config_port)
then the user could change the behavior by doing:
npm config set foo:port 80

environment variable is set to
whichever stage of the cycle is being executed. So, you could have a
single script used for different parts of the process which switches
based on what's currently happening.
Objects are flattened following this format, so if you had

in your package.json, then you'd
see this in the script:
process.env.npm_package_scripts_install === "foo.js"
For example, if your package.json contains this:

{
  "scripts": {
    "install": "scripts/install.js",
    "postinstall": "scripts/install.js",
    "uninstall": "scripts/uninstall.js"
  }
}

will be called for the install
and post-install stages of the lifecycle, and
will be called when the package is uninstalled. Since

is running for two different phases, it would
be wise in this case to look at the

If you want to run a make command, you can do so. This works just
fine:

{
  "scripts": {
    "preinstall": "./configure",
    "install": "make && make install",
    "test": "make test"
  }
}
Scripts are run by passing the line as a script argument to

If the script exits with a code other than 0, then this will abort the
process.

Note that these script files don't have to be nodejs or even
javascript programs. They just have to be some kind of executable
file.

If you want to run a specific script at a specific lifecycle event for
ALL packages, then you can use a hook script.

, and
it'll get run for all packages when they are going through that point
in the package lifecycle for any packages installed in that root.

Hook scripts are run exactly the same way as package.json scripts.
That is, they are in a separate child process, with the env described
above.
Don't exit with a non-zero error code unless you

mean it.
Except for uninstall scripts, this will cause the npm action to
fail, and potentially be rolled back. If the failure is minor or
only will prevent some optional features, then it's better to just
print a warning and exit successfully.
Try not to use scripts to do what npm can do for you. Read through

to see all the things that you can specify and enable
by simply describing your package appropriately. In general, this
will lead to a more robust and consistent state.

Inspect the env to determine where to put things. For instance, if
the

, then
don't try to install executables into

. The user
probably set it up that way for a reason.

Don't prefix your script commands with "sudo". If root permissions
are required for some reason, then it'll fail with that error, and
the user will sudo the npm command in question.

for anything else. You should almost never have to explicitly set a
preinstall or install script. If you are doing this, please consider if
there is another option. The only valid use of
scripts is for compilation which must be done on the target architecture.
